image.altText: A barge at a port

items.synopsis: The British government says it's trying to "stop the boats", but one of its solutions — a giant, grey barge designed to house 500 asylum seekers — is proving controversial.

title.children: There's a floating 'recipe for disaster' off England's coast — it has links to Australia

image.altText: An illustration of a SARS-CoV-2 virus particle showing the protruding spike proteins on the virus's surface.

items.synopsis: A COVID-19 variant nicknamed "Eris" — after the Greek goddess of chaos, strife and discord — has been in the news after spreading overseas. But the variant has actually been in Australia for four months.

title.children: The 'goddess of chaos' COVID variant is making headlines, but it’s been lurking quietly for months

image.altText: Annie blows a whistle, standing alongside a rugby scrum in her jersey.

items.synopsis: Hardened rugby union referees are walking away from the game amid a dramatic surge in abuse, prompting Rugby Australia to dish out tougher sanctions to offenders.

image.altText: Anthony Albanese walking on a red dirt road surrounded by people in body paint carrying red flags

items.synopsis: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander agencies, Voice to Parliament advocates and the prime minister have described a conspiracy theory on the length of the Uluru Statement from the Heart as a misinformation campaign to avoid debating the facts.

image.altText: Graphic of Australian Bank logos on houses including Commonwealth, ANZ, Westpac, and National.

items.synopsis: The big banks were offering cashback deals and competitive rates to grab their share of the refinancing boom, but the trend has reversed as margins start to come under pressure, leaving some borrowers trapped between a mortgage cliff and a mortgage prison.

title.children: Why the honeymoon is over — banks pull back on fight for new borrowers

image.altText: People walk through the front door of a house, past a For Lease sign.

items.synopsis: About 30 per cent of Australians live in rental accommodation with growing numbers in seats that helped secure government for Labor. But the Greens want to win those votes and next week's National Cabinet will offer clues as to how determined Labor is to stop them, writes David Speers.

title.children: Next week is looming as an important moment for Australian housing

image.altText: Filipino marines standing on the deck of a rusty ship.

items.synopsis: For decades the Philippines have stationed a small contingent of marines on a rusting World War II warship that was deliberately run aground on a submerged reef in the South China Sea.

title.children: Why is China so keen to stop resupply ships reaching a dilapidated warship stuck on a South China Sea reef?

items.synopsis: Legislation to establish the Parliamentary Workplace Support Service is the first major tranche of legislation to deal with the recommendations made by former Sex Discrimination Commissioner.

title.children: Legislation to establish parliament human resources agency tabled two years after sexual harassment review

image.altText: a camera and silhouette of a woman beside it

items.synopsis: The Queensland mother is facing the prospect of having nowhere to live after raising concerns about security cameras inside their rental property. She became so concerned she and her children left the property.

image.altText: Wild Mushroom Death Cap

items.synopsis: The deaths of three Victorians after a Saturday lunch in the small town of Leongatha sent shock waves through the community, but also shone the spotlight on one of the most poisonous organisms on earth.

items.synopsis: The Canadian-born Robertson was a high school dropout who fell in love with the seemingly limitless sounds and byways of his adopted US.

title.children: Robbie Robertson, lead guitarist and songwriter of The Band, dies at 80

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The opposition will no longer attempt to unwind the government's scheme to halve the cost of hundreds of medications, asking instead for the government to take its act of "good faith" as a chance to redesign the scheme. Read more here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Opposition withdraws attempt to stop government plan for half-price medications

featuredLink.title: Coalition withdraws attempt to unwind half-price medication scheme, asking for government to delay start date

children.content: The opposition will no longer attempt to unwind the government's scheme to halve the cost of hundreds of medications, asking instead for the government to take its act of "good faith" as a chance to redesign the scheme.
Read more here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The federal government has formally abandoned plans to build a low-level nuclear waste dump near Kimba, in regional South Australia. Last month the Federal Court ruled in favour of the area’s traditional owners, the Barngarla people, who had argued they were not properly consulted by the former Coalition government about the decision to pick the site. In parliament, Resources Minister Madeleine King said the government respected the decision and would not pursue building the facility at Napandee. She said all work on the site would cease.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Federal government formally abandons nuclear waste dump site in regional SA

children.content: The federal government has formally abandoned plans to build a low-level nuclear waste dump near Kimba, in regional South Australia.
Last month
the Federal Court ruled in favour of the area’s traditional owners
, the Barngarla people, who had argued they were not properly consulted by the former Coalition government about the decision to pick the site.
In parliament, Resources Minister Madeleine King said the government respected the decision and would not pursue building the facility at Napandee.
She said all work on the site would cease.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A 19-year-old charged over a crash that killed five teenagers south of Sydney last year has pleaded guilty in Picton Local Court. Three girls and two boys, aged between 14 and 16, died in the crash last September when the ute Tyrell Edwards was driving slammed into a tree at Buxton. You can read more here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Teenager pleads guilty over ute crash which killed five others south of Sydney

featuredLink.title: Teen driver pleads guilty over crash the killed five friends south of Sydney

children.content: A 19-year-old charged over a
crash that killed five teenagers south of Sydney last year has pleaded guilty in Picton Local Court.
Three girls and two boys, aged between 14 and 16, died in the crash last September when the ute Tyrell Edwards was driving slammed into a tree at Buxton.
You can read more here:

items.synopsis: Actor, comedian and author Denise Scott tells the Australian Women's Weekly in an exclusive interview she was diagnosed with cancer immediately before she was due to start filming the Mother and Son remake.

title.children: Denise Scott opens up about filming Mother and Son while dealing with cancer

image.altText: A man in a hat and coat plays a guitar on stage.

title.children: Rodriguez, subject of Searching for Sugar Man documentary, dies at 81

image.altText: Rodriguez sits on the porch of a house

items.synopsis: Midnight Oil's former manager Zev Eizik booked the singer's first Australian tour in the 1970s. It didn't start off well.

title.children: Australia was early in embracing Rodriguez, a talent chewed up by the music industry

image.altText: A stylised graphic of the ASX board with an up arrow.

items.synopsis: Wall Street indices fall overnight but the Australian share market looks set to buck the trend and rise in early trade.

title.children: Wall Street falls, Australian market set to defy downward lead

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: AMP has posted a 44% drop in net profit to $261 million for the half-year ended on June 30, 2023. Its result was boosted by a $209 million gain on the sale of its international infrastructure equity business, while the previous year's first-half result was even more inflated by the sale of its real estate and domestic infrastructure business. Looking at only the businesses that AMP continues to operate, net profit came in at $52 million, down 45% from the previous first-half result. AMP said its underlying profit results were roughly in line with the first-half last year at $112 million. The company said its banking division saw a 24% rise in profit, while its investment platform saw underlying profits up nearly 26%. Its advice business posted a $25 million underlying loss, although AMP said this was smaller than last year. "We have significantly reduced the size and complexity of AMP's business, whilst continuing to resolve legacy issues," said the financial firm's CEO Alexis George. "We have outlined a target to deliver $120 million in run rate controllable cost savings by FY 25, with a $60 million reduction in FY 24 and a similar number for FY 25. "This will be achieved through simplifying our technology architecture, removing stranded costs, reducing group costs including property, continued focus on the Advice business, replatforming our Master Trust business and a disciplined approach to project spend." Between divestments and cost-cutting, AMP is striving to shrink its way back to greatness.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: AMP profits drop as company deals with 'legacy issues'

children.content: AMP has posted a 44% drop in net profit to $261 million
for the half-year ended on June 30, 2023.
Its result was boosted by
a $209 million gain on the sale of its international infrastructure equity business
, while the previous year's first-half result was even more inflated by the sale of its real estate and domestic infrastructure business.
Looking at only the businesses that AMP continues to operate,
net profit came in at $52 million, down 45%
from the previous first-half result.
AMP said its
underlying profit results
were roughly in line with the first-half last year at
$112 million
The company said its
banking division saw a 24% rise in profit
, while its
investment platform saw underlying profits up nearly 26%
Its
advice business posted a $25 million underlying loss
, although AMP said this was smaller than last year.
"We have significantly reduced the size and complexity of AMP's business, whilst continuing to resolve legacy issues," said the financial firm's CEO Alexis George.
"We have outlined a target to deliver $120 million in run rate controllable cost savings by FY 25, with a $60 million reduction in FY 24 and a similar number for FY 25.

"This will be achieved through simplifying our technology architecture, removing stranded costs, reducing group costs including property, continued focus on the Advice business, replatforming our Master Trust business and a disciplined approach to project spend."
Between divestments and cost-cutting, AMP is striving to shrink its way back to greatness.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: European gas futures prices jumped 28% overnight, apparently mainly on news that there might be strikes at some of Western Australia's key gas export facilities. This from NAB's Rodrigo Catril : "Reuters notes that collectively monthly exports from the facilities equate to around 11% of exports globally, highlighting the risk of a supply squeeze as we head towards winter in the northern hemisphere. "The AFR noted about 99% of 180 production employees at Woodside's facilities voted for action, including indefinite strikes, and they shall be soon joined by hundreds of other employees at Chevron's facilities. "Strikes could start as early as next week."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian LNG strike threat boosts European gas prices

children.content: European gas futures prices jumped 28% overnight, apparently mainly on news that there
might be strikes at some of Western Australia's key gas export facilities
This from
NAB's Rodrigo Catril

"Reuters notes that collectively monthly exports from the facilities equate to around 11% of exports globally, highlighting the risk of a supply squeeze as we head towards winter in the northern hemisphere.

"The AFR noted about 99% of 180 production employees at Woodside's facilities voted for action, including indefinite strikes, and they shall be soon joined by hundreds of other employees at Chevron's facilities.
"Strikes could start as early as next week."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The big result out of the US overnight was Disney, which was a mixed bag. The bright spot was 13% revenue growth for its theme parks, products and experiences division. However, the company lamented some disappointing box office results for films including Elemental and the latest Indiana Jones adventure. It also reported another drop in subscriber numbers for Disney+ to 146.1 million, down 7.4%, mainly due to the loss of broadcasting rights for Indian Premier League cricket. The relevant Disney+ Hotstar product lost 24% of its users. Earnings per share were slightly higher on an adjusted basis, while revenue was a touch lower than typical forecasts. The broadcaster took $US2.65 billion in one-time write-downs and charges, which dragged it to a $US460 million net loss.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Disney loses subscribers after missing out on Indian cricket rights

The relevant

product lost 24% of its users.
Earnings per share were slightly higher on an adjusted basis, while revenue was a touch lower than typical forecasts.
The broadcaster took
$US2.65 billion in one-time write-downs and charges
, which dragged it to a $US460 million net loss.

image.altText: A woman with long dark hair looking at the camera.
